origin.origPlace: Kuḍā, Cave No. 5, in the left end of the verandah.

div.p: This edition is based on Burgess and Indraji 1881; the translation has been slightly adapted. Note that Georg Bühler considered Pātimita in the text to be a mistake for Sātimita (Svātimitra).

siddhaṃ therāṇaṃ bhadata pātimitana bhadaṃta
āgimitana ca bhāgiṇeyiya pāva
yitikāya nāginikāya duhutaya pāva
yitikāya padumaṃnikāya deya dhaṃmaṃ
leṇaṃ poḍhī ca sahā atevāsiniya bodhiya
Two letters, ya-ma, added beyond the end of this line, are only lightly cut and look recent; if inserted where the mark indicates they make Mayabodhī; if we read mātuya bodhiya it might be translated by “her female discipline’s mother Bodhi and of her female discipline Asālhamitā.”
saha ca ativāsiniya asālhamitāya

Success! A cave and a cistern, the charitable gift of the female ascetic Padumanikā, daugher of Nāginikā the ascetic, the sister’s daughter of the Thera Bhadaṃta Svātimitra and Bhadaṃta Agnimitra, and, of her female disciplines Bodhi and Aṣāḍhamitrā
